story:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled at the foot of a great mountain, there lived a kind and wise Buddhist mother named Sela. She had a young son named Taro, who was curious about the world and full of questions.

One night, as Taro lay in bed, he looked up at the stars twinkling in the sky and asked, "Mother, what are stars made of?"

Sela smiled and replied, "Stars are made of the same things as everything else in the universe, Taro. They are made of the four elements: earth, water, air, and fire."

"But mother, how can that be? The stars are so far away and they shine so brightly!" Taro exclaimed.

"That is true, Taro, but everything in the universe is connected," Sela explained. "Even though the stars are far away, they are still a part of the same fabric of existence as us. They are made of the same energy and matter that make up our own bodies and the world around us."

Taro thought about this for a moment and then asked, "But mother, why do the stars shine?"

Sela replied, "The stars shine because they are constantly undergoing a process of creation and destruction. They are like great cosmic fires, burning with the energy of the elements. As they burn, they release light and heat, which we see as starlight."

Taro's eyes grew wide with wonder. "That is so beautiful, mother. It makes me feel connected to the stars and to the whole universe."

Sela smiled and nodded. "Yes, Taro, that is the beauty of the universe. We are all connected, and we are all a part of something much larger than ourselves. Now, close your eyes and let the light of the stars guide you into a peaceful sleep."

And with that, Taro drifted off to sleep, feeling a sense of peace and connection to the universe. From that day on, he always looked up at the stars with a sense of wonder and awe, knowing that he was a part of something much larger than himself.

And so, Taro grew up to be a wise and compassionate young man, just like his mother. And they lived happily, always seeking to understand the mysteries of the universe and the interconnectedness of all things. The end.
